What is a factor?


The notion of a factor is relatively recent. Historically, in statistics all variables were analysed numerically. However, in the 80/90s, the concept of grouping variables was introduced. These are factors, and they quickly became prominent when handling data.


A factor variable is a variable that is built of several levels. Two attributes where a factor variable differs from a numerical variable are in Order and Magnitude.


One task when cleaning data is to recode factor levels. For example, if we look at the Omani data, we can see the variable sex has values 1 and 2. If we calculate the mean of this, we get 1.05 - this is not particularly insightful because sex is a factor variable. We therefore want to treat it as a factor.


Recoding a factor in a Spreadsheet Software


There are several approaches to recode a Factor variable in a spreadsheet software such as Excel - some of which may be more efficient in certain cases. Here, we address using filters to recode a variable.


For example, we take the Sex variable in the Omani data and filter to just when Sex is “1”. We want to replace all “1”’s with “Male”. To do this:

  1. Set the first value to be “Male”
  2. Then select the bottom right corner of that highlighted “Male” cell, and drag down. This will replace the other values with “Male”.
